That war is the principal means
through which humanity has risen
from the beast to its present high
development; that it once was profitable and justifiable, but is no longer
so; and that the pending arbitration
treaties between the United -States
and France and the United States
and England sound its death knell,
were the principal points made by
Dean Kirchwey of the Columbia
Law School in an address at the
meeting of the Maryland Peace Society, held in McCoy Hall last Friday night. The purpose of the
meeting was to urge the United
States Senate to ratify the treaties,
and a resolution to this effect was
passed.
Mr. Theodore Marburg, who held
the chair, reviewed the Senate's repeated chariness to pass arbitration
treaties and recalled its rejection of
the Olney-Pauncefoote treaty and
of the treaties arranged by Secretary Hay.
Among the other speakers were
Dean Charles L. Gregory, of the
Law School of George Washington University, and Rear-Admiral
Stockton, retired, of the United
States Navy. Admiral Stockton
spoke of the treaties from the standpoint of a practical fighting man,
Dean Kirchwey said that the objection to the ratification of the
treaties were of three kinds: Legal,
sentimental and practical. As to the
first, he said that the Senate would
by no means be surrendering any
real prerogative in ratifying the
general treaty; as to the practical,
that it is almost beyond the bounds
of human probability that, under the
methods arranged by the treaty, any
dispute will be referred to arbitration which should not be so referred; and as to the sentimental,
that in this age an arbitration treaty
is not mere waste-paper, but a real
fact, faithfully to be observed.
Gillet Elected Captain.

At a dinner given to the football
men on Thursday evening, at the
Hotel Emerson, after the game,
George M. Gillet, Jr., '13, was
elected captain for next year. The
dinner was given by Mr. J. Pembroke Thom, one of the graduate
advisers.
Speeches were made by Captain
Fulton, Captain-elect Gillet, and
Mr. Thom. Mr. B. Howell Griswold, Jr., read some original lyrics
on the St. John's funeral.

Hopkins,51 ; opponents, 104. The
figures tell the story of the football
season just closed. Nor is the result much more satisfactory when
the Carlisle and Navy games are
omitted—Hopkins, 40; opponents,
48. The remaining teams are those
against which Hopkins might reasonably be expected to make a good
showing. Virginia, it is true, is a
tough proposition, but the ambition
to climb into a better class of athletic relations can never be gratified
until Hopkins can show herself
able to handle teams of the calibre
of Virginia. And yet the retrospect is not so dark, after all. There
remains .the St. John's game, with
its 2 to i odds and its newspaper
prophecies of defeat all overturned
by an exhibition of good, honest
football that outclassed the soldier
boys. As long as the St. John's
game is a victory, the Hopkins football season is a success.
Yet even in the victory there was
a very unfortunate element. It
brought the climax of the season
too early. Enthusiasm that had
been aroused to a high pitch before
the Virginia game, reached its crest
the next Saturday, and then suddenly dropped away to such an extent that Western Maryland defeated a team that had let down
deplorably in tone from what it had
been two weeks before, and that
was feebly supported by only a
handful of cheerers and a hired •
band. The past season has been a
warning to those who attempt to
predict what will be and what might
have been in football, but it is hard
to believe that the result would have
been the same if the Western Maryland game had come before that
with St. John's.
But if the schedule is open to
criticism in this respect, the management is to be congratulated on
the whole for the admirable aribangements that were made for the
games. The Athletic Board and
the managers have a difficult situation to face here in Baltimore, and
they deserve credit for the tact that
is called for constantly. There are,
an endless number of details about
the seating of the crowds, the accommodations for the players, the
prices to be charged, the advertising to be displayed, the cheering,
and whatnot, and almost anyone of
these details may be arranged in
an endless number of ways. It is
impossible to fix everything to suit
everybody, •and at the same time
the "Homewood habit" is still so

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 4, 1911
Another Tradition Gone.
Football at Hopkins.

THE Yms-LETT4R prints today
three articles, which should be of
interest to those who have the welfare of Hopkins football at heart.
The first is a review of the season,
which has been, to say the least,
disappointing. Our schedule, it is
true, was a hard one, and three defeats were to be expected. The St.
John's game was won by a big
score, but that doesn't make up for
the miserable showing against Western Maryland on Thursday, our inferiority to Gettysburg, the failure
to score against Maryland Agricultural College, except on a fluke,
and the inability to cross Gallaudet's
goal line except on a long run in
the last part of the final period.
It has already been urged that
Hopkins should establish a fouryear rule, so that its football teams
would have to be developed, instead
of relying on former stars who are
unable to attend practice regularly,
but who, on the strength of their
reputations, are given places in the
line-up and depended upon, often
vainly, to be in physical condition
to play four gruelling periods and
work together like a well-oiled, perfectly • trained machine. With a
four-year rule, it is argued, the
eleven men in the game, if not stars
of former glory, would form a team
and would be constantly developing,
so that this year's post-St. John's
slump wouldn't be duplicated.
This season's experience, however, has not been due to the lack
of a four-year rule. Even if we
had an elastic arrangernent by which
alumni could come back and play,
there would be no serious injury to
Hopkins football, so long as the
coaches knew their business. That
has been our salient weakness this
year—the inadequacy of the coaching department. With able coaches, the existence or non-existence
of the four-year rule wouldn't matter. In this connection, the letter

There was no cane rush between
the halves of the football game on
Saturday, and arkother of the few
remaining Hopkins traditions went
by the board and scarcely caused
a ripple. The rush was forbidden
by the authorities, because there
weren't enough freshmen in condition to take part, although in its
modified form of the last four years,
the battle for the cane is anything
but dangerous.
We are cooped up here in the
center of the city, with no campus
or dormitories, and it is not remarkable that with the small student
body there are not more customs.
But an effort certainly should be
made to hold fast to those which
have been started. This year, the
so-called rules that a freshman may
not ride in the elevator until after
Thanksgiving, and may not wear
his hat in McCoy Hall until after
the interclass game, were openly
violated and no one objected. The
class-rush has become a mere exchange of pleasantries, and it would
not take away any of its roughness
if tea were served in the intermissions. The Hullabaloo hasn't
seen the light of day since 1909,
and the class pictures weren't taken
last year.
We have no. class day exercises,
with the planting of ivy or other
sentimental but very dear customs,
which are regarded by the graduates at other institutiOns. At Hopkins, the fourth-year men hire
gowns, attend the Commencement,
get their diplomas and then disperse. The only functions which
serve to make graduation something real and to be remembered,
are those given by the President
and Dean and the Senior Prom.
It is well enough to say that
when we get to Homewood we will
start some customs, but they can't
be started. They have to grow,and
they are of no account so long as
they remain rules.

THE NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 4, 1911.
Meeting the Co-eds, and Then--

THE NEWS-LETTER has received
the following puzzler for its query
column:
DEAR GASSY Gus—I can walk up to

a fellow, slap him on the back, and introduce myself. Is it etiquette for me
to do this with a co-ed? There are
one or two that I want to meet, but I
can't engineer it. '

MALE UNDERGRADUATE.

This is a problem which some
members of THE NEWS-LETTER
Board have been considering privately for some time, because there
are some co-eds that they want to
meet, but can't arrange it. The graduate students are especially favored,
for they associate in the classes with
the fair members, and speaking relations can be very easily established in that fashion. The professor calls on Miss B., who is nonplussed for a moment. Then she
hears the necessary information
given sotto-voce by her masculine
neighbor, and she flashes him a
thankful glance. Who would deny
that these two have been introduced?
Or, everyone will be agreed that
it would be perfectly proper for a
male student to say to a female one,
after the bell has rung and the
agony is over: "Rotten lecture today, wasn't it? You can bet your
Puffs that I am glad that I only
'have two hours of this torture every
week." And the co-ed, if she was
worthy of associating with real students in the classroom, would make
a courteous reply. The next scene
would be in Gordon's—pardon me,
in the Dutch Tea Room, or in the
Maryland. When a professor calls
the roll, it is universally understood
that he is introducing the various
members of the class. The problem
for the graduate students is, therefore, a simple one. The undergraduate question is different, but it
is THE NEWS-LETTER'S firm belief
that, provided the undergraduate is
Presentable, and goes about it in a
right manner, he would be perfectly
justified in attempting to get acquainted.'
There are ladies in each of the
laboratories, and every scientific
student speaks to them. He would
be deemed impolite if he didn't, but
the introductions are few and far

"Going out to the game, Saturday ?" is the feelerS number two,
said in a casual matter-of-fact tone.
"I hadn't thought ninch. about it,
but will be glad to go with you,"
Miss B. replies eagerly, and everything is settled. The two then tell
each other their names; the man
learns where to call; arrives on the
dot and has to wait the customary
fifteen minutes. They Converse in
the usual fashion on the walk or
ride to Homewood; walk the gantlet to their seats; the girlish treble
and manly basso cheer together, and
then home to the boarding-house.
The usual invitation to call again,
is given and accepted.
The Ladies' Home Journal, which
we understand the Library is soon
to put in the reading-room for the
co-eds, says that when two, people
meet under the same roof, in the
house of a mutual friend, at a dance
or reception, for instance, they
should recognize each other. Certainly, the case at Hopkins is identical. We all meet under one roof,
in the house presided over by President Remsen, and we should recognize each other. This is THE NEWSLETTER'S advice . to "Male Undergraduate." Let those who want to,
try. They can do no more than
fail. If those turned down will
send their names to "Gassy Gus,"
THE NEWS-LETTER will be pleased
to arrange for a reception at which
the, necessary formal introductions
can be performed.
To act as a matrimonial bureau
is somewhat outside of the function
of a student publication, but toward
the close of the year when the
parlous financial times begin, we
wouldn't mind in the least having
some fat fees slipped us from those
mutual adorers whom we have enabled to find one another.
If, on the other hand, there are
any co-eds who would like to meet
handsome undergraduates,they need
only send their names to "Gassy
Gus," and he will see that their desires are fulfilled. All communications will, of course, be in confidence.

between. There are telephone operators and library assistants, and-

speaking relations are maintained
With these. True, that the ordinary
routine brings the student into contact with the ladies who, THE
NEWS-LETTER has declared, greatly enhance the quality of English
Which is used at Hopkins. But the
same thing might be done with the
Co-eds. Mr. A. meets Miss B. in
the corridor, or elevator.
"Deucedly warm in here, don't
You know," he advances tentatively.
"Do you think so?" is the doubtful reply, while Miss B. dives into
her carry-all for a powder puff and
surreptitiously whitens the tip of
her delicious nose. That's the way
a novel would accomplish the introduction. The next step would be
easier.

That war is the principal means
through which humanity has risen
from the beast to its present high
development; that it once was profitable and justifiable, but is no longer
so; and that the pending arbitration
treaties between the United -States
and France and the United States
and England sound its death knell,
were the principal points made by
Dean Kirchwey of the Columbia
Law School in an address at the
meeting of the Maryland Peace Society, held in McCoy Hall last Friday night. The purpose of the
meeting was to urge the United
States Senate to ratify the treaties,
and a resolution to this effect was
passed.
Mr. Theodore Marburg, who held
the chair, reviewed the Senate's repeated chariness to pass arbitration
treaties and recalled its rejection of
the Olney-Pauncefoote treaty and
of the treaties arranged by Secretary Hay.
Among the other speakers were
Dean Charles L. Gregory, of the
Law School of George Washington University, and Rear-Admiral
Stockton, retired, of the United
States Navy. Admiral Stockton
spoke of the treaties from the standpoint of a practical fighting man,
Dean Kirchwey said that the objection to the ratification of the
treaties were of three kinds: Legal,
sentimental and practical. As to the
first, he said that the Senate would
by no means be surrendering any
real prerogative in ratifying the
general treaty; as to the practical,
that it is almost beyond the bounds
of human probability that, under the
methods arranged by the treaty, any
dispute will be referred to arbitration which should not be so referred; and as to the sentimental,
that in this age an arbitration treaty
is not mere waste-paper, but a real
fact, faithfully to be observed.
Gillet Elected Captain.

At a dinner given to the football
men on Thursday evening, at the
Hotel Emerson, after the game,
George M. Gillet, Jr., '13, was
elected captain for next year. The
dinner was given by Mr. J. Pembroke Thom, one of the graduate
advisers.
Speeches were made by Captain
Fulton, Captain-elect Gillet, and
Mr. Thom. Mr. B. Howell Griswold, Jr., read some original lyrics
on the St. John's funeral.

Hopkins,51 ; opponents, 104. The
figures tell the story of the football
season just closed. Nor is the result much more satisfactory when
the Carlisle and Navy games are
omitted—Hopkins, 40; opponents,
48. The remaining teams are those
against which Hopkins might reasonably be expected to make a good
showing. Virginia, it is true, is a
tough proposition, but the ambition
to climb into a better class of athletic relations can never be gratified
until Hopkins can show herself
able to handle teams of the calibre
of Virginia. And yet the retrospect is not so dark, after all. There
remains .the St. John's game, with
its 2 to i odds and its newspaper
prophecies of defeat all overturned
by an exhibition of good, honest
football that outclassed the soldier
boys. As long as the St. John's
game is a victory, the Hopkins football season is a success.
Yet even in the victory there was
a very unfortunate element. It
brought the climax of the season
too early. Enthusiasm that had
been aroused to a high pitch before
the Virginia game, reached its crest
the next Saturday, and then suddenly dropped away to such an extent that Western Maryland defeated a team that had let down
deplorably in tone from what it had
been two weeks before, and that
was feebly supported by only a
handful of cheerers and a hired •
band. The past season has been a
warning to those who attempt to
predict what will be and what might
have been in football, but it is hard
to believe that the result would have
been the same if the Western Maryland game had come before that
with St. John's.
But if the schedule is open to
criticism in this respect, the management is to be congratulated on
the whole for the admirable aribangements that were made for the
games. The Athletic Board and
the managers have a difficult situation to face here in Baltimore, and
they deserve credit for the tact that
is called for constantly. There are,
an endless number of details about
the seating of the crowds, the accommodations for the players, the
prices to be charged, the advertising to be displayed, the cheering,
and whatnot, and almost anyone of
these details may be arranged in
an endless number of ways. It is
impossible to fix everything to suit
everybody, •and at the same time
the "Homewood habit" is still so

LEMMERT

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 4, 1911
Another Tradition Gone.
Football at Hopkins.

THE Yms-LETT4R prints today
three articles, which should be of
interest to those who have the welfare of Hopkins football at heart.
The first is a review of the season,
which has been, to say the least,
disappointing. Our schedule, it is
true, was a hard one, and three defeats were to be expected. The St.
John's game was won by a big
score, but that doesn't make up for
the miserable showing against Western Maryland on Thursday, our inferiority to Gettysburg, the failure
to score against Maryland Agricultural College, except on a fluke,
and the inability to cross Gallaudet's
goal line except on a long run in
the last part of the final period.
It has already been urged that
Hopkins should establish a fouryear rule, so that its football teams
would have to be developed, instead
of relying on former stars who are
unable to attend practice regularly,
but who, on the strength of their
reputations, are given places in the
line-up and depended upon, often
vainly, to be in physical condition
to play four gruelling periods and
work together like a well-oiled, perfectly • trained machine. With a
four-year rule, it is argued, the
eleven men in the game, if not stars
of former glory, would form a team
and would be constantly developing,
so that this year's post-St. John's
slump wouldn't be duplicated.
This season's experience, however, has not been due to the lack
of a four-year rule. Even if we
had an elastic arrangernent by which
alumni could come back and play,
there would be no serious injury to
Hopkins football, so long as the
coaches knew their business. That
has been our salient weakness this
year—the inadequacy of the coaching department. With able coaches, the existence or non-existence
of the four-year rule wouldn't matter. In this connection, the letter

There was no cane rush between
the halves of the football game on
Saturday, and arkother of the few
remaining Hopkins traditions went
by the board and scarcely caused
a ripple. The rush was forbidden
by the authorities, because there
weren't enough freshmen in condition to take part, although in its
modified form of the last four years,
the battle for the cane is anything
but dangerous.
We are cooped up here in the
center of the city, with no campus
or dormitories, and it is not remarkable that with the small student
body there are not more customs.
But an effort certainly should be
made to hold fast to those which
have been started. This year, the
so-called rules that a freshman may
not ride in the elevator until after
Thanksgiving, and may not wear
his hat in McCoy Hall until after
the interclass game, were openly
violated and no one objected. The
class-rush has become a mere exchange of pleasantries, and it would
not take away any of its roughness
if tea were served in the intermissions. The Hullabaloo hasn't
seen the light of day since 1909,
and the class pictures weren't taken
last year.
We have no. class day exercises,
with the planting of ivy or other
sentimental but very dear customs,
which are regarded by the graduates at other institutiOns. At Hopkins, the fourth-year men hire
gowns, attend the Commencement,
get their diplomas and then disperse. The only functions which
serve to make graduation something real and to be remembered,
are those given by the President
and Dean and the Senior Prom.
It is well enough to say that
when we get to Homewood we will
start some customs, but they can't
be started. They have to grow,and
they are of no account so long as
they remain rules.

THE NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 4, 1911.
Meeting the Co-eds, and Then--

THE NEWS-LETTER has received
the following puzzler for its query
column:
DEAR GASSY Gus—I can walk up to

a fellow, slap him on the back, and introduce myself. Is it etiquette for me
to do this with a co-ed? There are
one or two that I want to meet, but I
can't engineer it. '

MALE UNDERGRADUATE.

This is a problem which some
members of THE NEWS-LETTER
Board have been considering privately for some time, because there
are some co-eds that they want to
meet, but can't arrange it. The graduate students are especially favored,
for they associate in the classes with
the fair members, and speaking relations can be very easily established in that fashion. The professor calls on Miss B., who is nonplussed for a moment. Then she
hears the necessary information
given sotto-voce by her masculine
neighbor, and she flashes him a
thankful glance. Who would deny
that these two have been introduced?
Or, everyone will be agreed that
it would be perfectly proper for a
male student to say to a female one,
after the bell has rung and the
agony is over: "Rotten lecture today, wasn't it? You can bet your
Puffs that I am glad that I only
'have two hours of this torture every
week." And the co-ed, if she was
worthy of associating with real students in the classroom, would make
a courteous reply. The next scene
would be in Gordon's—pardon me,
in the Dutch Tea Room, or in the
Maryland. When a professor calls
the roll, it is universally understood
that he is introducing the various
members of the class. The problem
for the graduate students is, therefore, a simple one. The undergraduate question is different, but it
is THE NEWS-LETTER'S firm belief
that, provided the undergraduate is
Presentable, and goes about it in a
right manner, he would be perfectly
justified in attempting to get acquainted.'
There are ladies in each of the
laboratories, and every scientific
student speaks to them. He would
be deemed impolite if he didn't, but
the introductions are few and far

"Going out to the game, Saturday ?" is the feelerS number two,
said in a casual matter-of-fact tone.
"I hadn't thought ninch. about it,
but will be glad to go with you,"
Miss B. replies eagerly, and everything is settled. The two then tell
each other their names; the man
learns where to call; arrives on the
dot and has to wait the customary
fifteen minutes. They Converse in
the usual fashion on the walk or
ride to Homewood; walk the gantlet to their seats; the girlish treble
and manly basso cheer together, and
then home to the boarding-house.
The usual invitation to call again,
is given and accepted.
The Ladies' Home Journal, which
we understand the Library is soon
to put in the reading-room for the
co-eds, says that when two, people
meet under the same roof, in the
house of a mutual friend, at a dance
or reception, for instance, they
should recognize each other. Certainly, the case at Hopkins is identical. We all meet under one roof,
in the house presided over by President Remsen, and we should recognize each other. This is THE NEWSLETTER'S advice . to "Male Undergraduate." Let those who want to,
try. They can do no more than
fail. If those turned down will
send their names to "Gassy Gus,"
THE NEWS-LETTER will be pleased
to arrange for a reception at which
the, necessary formal introductions
can be performed.
To act as a matrimonial bureau
is somewhat outside of the function
of a student publication, but toward
the close of the year when the
parlous financial times begin, we
wouldn't mind in the least having
some fat fees slipped us from those
mutual adorers whom we have enabled to find one another.
If, on the other hand, there are
any co-eds who would like to meet
handsome undergraduates,they need
only send their names to "Gassy
Gus," and he will see that their desires are fulfilled. All communications will, of course, be in confidence.

between. There are telephone operators and library assistants, and-

speaking relations are maintained
With these. True, that the ordinary
routine brings the student into contact with the ladies who, THE
NEWS-LETTER has declared, greatly enhance the quality of English
Which is used at Hopkins. But the
same thing might be done with the
Co-eds. Mr. A. meets Miss B. in
the corridor, or elevator.
"Deucedly warm in here, don't
You know," he advances tentatively.
"Do you think so?" is the doubtful reply, while Miss B. dives into
her carry-all for a powder puff and
surreptitiously whitens the tip of
her delicious nose. That's the way
a novel would accomplish the introduction. The next step would be
easier.
